Symmetry is not restricted to the visual arts. Its role in the history of [[music]] touches many aspects of the creation and perception of music.
====Musical form====
Symmetry has been used as a [[musical form|formal]] constraint by many composers, such as the [[arch form|arch (swell) form]] (ABCBA) used by [[Steve Reich]], [[Béla Bartók]], and [[James Tenney]]. In classical music, Bach used the symmetry concepts of permutation and invariance.<ref>see ("Fugue No. 21," [http://jan.ucc.nau.edu/~tas3/wtc/ii21s.pdf pdf] or [http://jan.ucc.nau.edu/~tas3/wtc/ii21.html Shockwave])</ref>
====Pitch structures==== Symmetry is also an important consideration in the formation of [[scale (music)|scale]]s and [[chord (music)|chords]], traditional or [[tonality|tonal]] music being made up of non-symmetrical groups of [[pitch (music)|pitches]], such as the [[diatonic scale]] or the [[major chord]]. [[Symmetrical scale]]s or chords, such as the [[whole tone scale]], [[augmented chord]], or diminished [[seventh chord]] (diminished-diminished seventh), are said to lack direction or a sense of forward motion, are [[ambiguous]] as to the [[Key (music)|key]] or tonal center, and have a less specific [[diatonic functionality]]. However, composers such as [[Alban Berg]], [[Béla Bartók]], and [[George Perle]] have used axes of symmetry and/or [[interval cycle]]s in an analogous way to [[musical key|keys]] or non-[[tonality|tonal]] tonal [[Tonic (music)|center]]s.<ref name=Perle1992>{{Cite journal |title=Symmetry, the twelve-tone scale, and tonality |first=George |last=Perle |authorlink=George Perle |journal=Contemporary Music Review |volume=6 |issue=2 |year=1992 |pages=81–96 |doi=10.1080/07494469200640151}}</ref> George Perle explains "C–E, D–F♯, [and] Eb–G, are different instances of the same [[interval (music)|interval]] … the other kind of identity. … has to do with axes of symmetry. C–E belongs to a family of symmetrically related dyads as follows:"<ref name=Perle1992/>
{| |- |D | |D♯ | |'''E''' | |F | |F♯ | |G | |G♯ |- |D | |C♯ | |'''C''' | |B | |A♯ | |A | |G♯ |}
Thus in addition to being part of the interval-4 family, C–E is also a part of the sum-4 family (with C equal to 0).<ref name=Perle1992/>
{| |rowspan=3|+ |2 | |3 | |'''4''' | |5 | |6 | |7 | |8 |- |2 | |1 | |'''0''' | |11 | |10 | |9 | |8 |- |4 | |4 | |4 | |4 | |4 | |4 | |4 |}
Interval cycles are symmetrical and thus non-diatonic. However, a seven pitch segment of C5 (the cycle of fifths, which are [[enharmonic]] with the cycle of fourths) will produce the diatonic major scale. Cyclic tonal [[chord progression|progressions]] in the works of [[Romantic music|Romantic]] composers such as [[Gustav Mahler]] and [[Richard Wagner]] form a link with the cyclic pitch successions in the atonal music of Modernists such as Bartók, [[Alexander Scriabin]], [[Edgard Varèse]], and the Vienna school. At the same time, these progressions signal the end of tonality.<ref name=Perle1992/><ref name="Perle1990">{{cite book |authorlink=George Perle |author=Perle, George |year=1990 |title=The Listening Composer |url=https://archive.org/details/listeningcompose00perl |url-access=limited |page=[https://archive.org/details/listeningcompose00perl/page/n31 21] |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=978-0-520-06991-6}}</ref>
The first extended composition consistently based on symmetrical pitch relations was probably Alban Berg's [[String Quartet (Berg)|''Quartet'', Op. 3]] (1910).<ref name="Perle1990"/>
====Equivalency====
[[Tone row]]s or [[pitch class]] [[Set theory (music)|sets]] which are [[Invariant (music)|invariant]] under [[Permutation (music)|retrograde]] are horizontally symmetrical, under [[Melodic inversion|inversion]] vertically. See also [[Asymmetric rhythm]].
===In quilts=== [[File:kitchen kaleid.svg|thumb|upright=0.65|left|Kitchen [[kaleidoscope]] [[quilt]] block]]
As [[quilt]]s are made from square blocks (usually 9, 16, or 25 pieces to a block) with each smaller piece usually consisting of fabric triangles, the craft lends itself readily to the application of symmetry.<ref>[http://its.guilford.k12.nc.us/webquests/quilts/quilts.htm Quate: Exploring Geometry Through Quilts] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031231031119/http://its.guilford.k12.nc.us/webquests/quilts/quilts.htm |date=2003-12-31 }}. Its.guilford.k12.nc.us. Retrieved on 2013-04-16.</ref>
===In other arts and crafts=== [[File:Zoomorphs.svg|thumb|upright=0.8|[[Celtic knot]]work showing [[Wallpaper group#Group p4 (442)|p4 symmetry]]]] {{Further|Islamic geometric patterns}}
Symmetries appear in the design of objects of all kinds. Examples include [[beadwork]], [[furniture]], [[sand painting]]s, [[knot]]work, [[masks]], and [[musical instruments]]. Symmetries are central to the art of [[M.C. Escher]] and the many applications of [[tessellation]] in art and craft forms such as [[wallpaper]], ceramic tilework such as in [[Islamic geometric patterns|Islamic geometric decoration]], [[batik]], [[ikat]], carpet-making, and many kinds of [[textile]] and [[embroidery]] patterns.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Cucker |first1=Felix |title=Manifold Mirrors: The Crossing Paths of the Arts and Mathematics |date=2013 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=978-0-521-72876-8 |pages=77–78, 83, 89, 103}}</ref>
Symmetry is also used in designing logos.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to Design a Perfect Logo with Grid and Symmetry|url=https://www.designmantic.com/how-to/how-to-design-a-perfect-logo}}</ref> By creating a logo on a grid and using the theory of symmetry, designers can organize their work, create a symmetric or asymmetrical design, determine the space between letters, determine how much negative space is required in the design, and how to accentuate parts of the logo to make it stand out.
===In aesthetics=== {{Main|Symmetry (physical attractiveness)}}
The relationship of symmetry to [[aesthetics]] is complex. Humans find [[bilateral symmetry]] in faces physically attractive;<ref name="Grammer1994">{{cite journal |last1=Grammer |first1=K. |last2=Thornhill |first2=R. |date=1994 |title=Human (Homo sapiens) facial attractiveness and sexual selection: the role of symmetry and averageness |journal=Journal of Comparative Psychology |location=Washington, D.C. |volume=108 |issue=3 |pages=233–42 |doi=10.1037/0735-7036.108.3.233|pmid=7924253 }}</ref> it indicates health and genetic fitness.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Rhodes |first1=Gillian |last2=Zebrowitz |first2=Leslie, A. |title=Facial Attractiveness - Evolutionary, Cognitive, and Social Perspectives |publisher=[[Ablex]] |year=2002 |isbn=1-56750-636-4}}</ref><ref name="Jones2001">Jones, B. C., Little, A. C., Tiddeman, B. P., Burt, D. M., & Perrett, D. I. (2001). Facial symmetry and judgements of apparent health Support for a “‘ good genes ’” explanation of the attractiveness – symmetry relationship, 22, 417–429.</ref> Opposed to this is the tendency for excessive symmetry to be perceived as boring or uninteresting. People prefer shapes that have some symmetry, but enough complexity to make them interesting.<ref>{{cite book |last=Arnheim |first=Rudolf |title=Visual Thinking |url=https://archive.org/details/visualthinking00rudo |url-access=registration |publisher=University of California Press |year=1969}}</ref>
===In literature=== Symmetry can be found in various forms in [[literature]], a simple example being the [[palindrome]] where a brief text reads the same forwards or backwards. Stories may have a symmetrical structure, as in the rise:fall pattern of ''[[Beowulf]]''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://trace.tennessee.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1925&context=utk_gradthes | title=Symmetrical Aesthetics of Beowulf | publisher=University of Tennessee, Knoxville | year=2009 |author1=Jenny Lea Bowman}}</ref>

{{short description|Smooth closed surface with g holes}}
In mathematics, a '''genus ''g'' surface''' (also known as a '''''g''-torus''' or '''''g''-holed torus''') is a [[Surface (topology)|surface]] formed by the [[connected sum]] of ''g'' many [[torus|tori]]: the interior of a disk is removed from each of ''g'' many tori and the boundaries of the ''g'' many disks are identified (glued together), forming a ''g''-torus. The [[genus (mathematics)|genus]] of such a surface is ''g''.
A genus ''g'' surface is a [[two-dimensional]] [[manifold]]. The [[Surface (topology)#Classification of closed surfaces|classification theorem for surfaces]] states that every [[compact space|compact]] [[connected space|connected]] two-dimensional manifold is [[homeomorphism|homeomorphic]] to either the sphere, the connected sum of tori, or the connected sum of [[real projective plane]]s.
==Definition of genus== {{Main|Genus (mathematics)}} The genus of a connected orientable surface is an [[integer]] representing the maximum number of cuttings along non-intersecting [[Curve#Topological_curve|closed simple curves]] without rendering the resultant [[manifold]] disconnected.<ref>Munkres, James R. Topology. Vol. 2. Upper Saddle River: Prentice Hall, 2000.</ref> It is equal to the number of [[Handle (mathematics)|handles]] on it. Alternatively, it can be defined in terms of the [[Euler characteristic]] ''χ'', via the relationship ''χ'' = 2 − 2''g'' for [[Surface_(topology)#Closed_surfaces|closed surfaces]], where ''g'' is the genus.
The genus (sometimes called the demigenus or Euler genus) of a connected non-orientable closed surface is a positive integer representing the number of [[cross-cap]]s attached to a sphere. Alternatively, it can be defined for a closed surface in terms of the Euler characteristic ''χ'', via the relationship ''χ'' = 2 − ''g'', where ''g'' is the non-orientable genus.
==Genus 0== An [[orientability|orientable]] surface of genus zero is the [[sphere]] '''''S''<sup>''2''</sup>'''. A non-orientable surface of genus zero is the [[disk (mathematics)|disc]].
<center> <gallery caption="Representations of genus 0 surfaces" widths="150" heights="150" perrow="5"> File:Sphere filled blue.svg|A sphere <math>S^2</math> File:1-ball.svg|A closed disc (with boundary) </gallery> </center>
==Genus 1== A genus one orientable surface is the ordinary torus. A non-orientable surface of genus one is the [[projective plane]].<ref>{{cite book| first=Glen E. | last=Bredon | authorlink=Glen Bredon | title=Topology and Geometry | publisher=Springer-Verlag | year=1993 | isbn=0-387-97926-3}}</ref>
[[Elliptic curve]]s over the complex numbers can be identified with genus 1 surfaces. The formulation of elliptic curves as the embedding of a [[torus]] in the [[complex projective plane]] follows naturally from a property of [[Weierstrass's elliptic functions]] that allows elliptic curves to be obtained from the quotient of the [[complex plane]] by a [[fundamental pair of periods|lattice]].<ref>{{Cite book | last = Silverman | first=Joseph H. | authorlink=Joseph H. Silverman | year = 1986 | title = The Arithmetic of Elliptic Curves | series = Graduate Texts in Mathematics | volume=106 | publisher = Springer-Verlag | isbn=0-387-96203-4 | ref = harv }}</ref>
<center> <gallery caption="Representations of genus 1 surfaces" widths="150" heights="150" perrow="5"> File:Torus illustration.png|A torus of genus 1 File:Elliptic curve simple.png|An elliptic curve </gallery> </center>
==Genus 2== The term '''double torus''' is occasionally used to denote a genus 2 surface.<ref>{{MathWorld |title=Double Torus |urlname=DoubleTorus}}</ref> A non-orientable surface of genus two is the [[Klein bottle]].
The [[Bolza surface]] is the most symmetric [[Riemann surface]] of [[Genus (mathematics)|genus]] 2, in the sense that it has the largest possible [[conformal map|conformal]] [[automorphism group]].<ref>{{citation|last=Bolza|first= Oskar|title=On Binary Sextics with Linear Transformations into Themselves|journal= American Journal of Mathematics|volume= 10|issue= 1|year= 1887|pages= 47–70|jstor=2369402|doi=10.2307/2369402}}</ref>
<center> <gallery caption="Representations of genus 2 surfaces" widths="150" heights="150" perrow="5"> File:Double torus illustration.png|A torus of genus 2 </gallery> </center>
==Genus 3== {{redirect|3-torus|the three-dimensional space|Three-torus}} The term '''triple torus''' is also occasionally used to denote a genus 3 surface.<ref>{{MathWorld |title=Triple Torus |urlname=TripleTorus}}</ref>
The [[Klein quartic]] is a compact [[Riemann surface]] of [[genus (mathematics)|genus]] {{math|3}} with the highest possible order [[automorphism group]] for compact Riemann surfaces of genus 3. It has namely order {{math|168}} orientation-preserving automorphisms, and {{math|336}} automorphisms if orientation may be reversed. <center> <gallery caption="Several genus 3 surfaces" widths="150" heights="150" perrow="5"> File:Sphere with three handles.png|A sphere with three [[handle (mathematics)|handles]] File:Triple torus array.png|The [[connected sum]] of three [[torus (mathematics)|tori]] File:Triple torus illustration.png|Triple torus File:Dodecagon with opposite faces identified.svg|[[Dodecagon]] with opposite edges identified{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} File:14-gon with opposite faces identified.svg|[[Tetradecagon]] with opposite edges identified{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}} </gallery> </center>
==See also== *[[Three-torus]] *[[g-torus knot]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources== * James R. Munkres, ''Topology, Second Edition'', Prentice-Hall, 2000, {{ISBN|0-13-181629-2}}. * William S. Massey, ''Algebraic Topology: An Introduction'', Harbrace, 1967.

[[File:Newton-Gauss Line Default Figure.png|thumb|The line created by connecting the midpoints of all diagonals (''L'', ''M'', and ''N'') is the Newton–Gauss Line.]] In [[geometry]], the '''Newton–Gauss line''' (or '''Gauss–Newton line''') is the [[Line (geometry)|line]] joining the [[midpoint]]s of the three [[diagonal]]s of a [[complete quadrangle]].
The midpoints of the two diagonals of a [[Convex set|convex]] [[quadrilateral]] with at most two parallel sides are distinct and thus determine a line, the [[Newton line]]. If the sides of such a quadrilateral are extended to form a complete quadrangle, the diagonals of the quadrilateral remain diagonals of the complete quadrangle and the Newton line of the quadrilateral is the Newton–Gauss line of the complete quadrangle. <!-- Hold until article is revised The Newton–Gauss line is very similar to the [[Newton line]], which follows the same general [[theorem]] but uses a convex [[quadrilateral]] with at most two parallel sides; this also means instead of having three [[diagonal]]s, it uses the [[midpoint]] of the two [[diagonal]]s in addition to the point which [[Bisection|bisects]] two lines created by connecting the [[midpoint]]s of the opposite sides of the [[quadrilateral]]. -->
== Complete quadrilaterals == {{main|Complete quadrilateral}}
Any four lines in [[general position]] (no two lines are parallel, and no three are concurrent) form a [[complete quadrilateral]]. This [[Configuration (geometry)|configuration]] consists of a total of six points, the intersection points of the four lines, with three points on each line and precisely two lines through each point.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/266061112_Gauss-Newton_lines_and_eleven_point_conics|title=Gauss–Newton Lines and Eleven Point Conics|last=Alperin|first=Roger C.|date=6 January 2012|website=Research Gate}}</ref> These six points can be split into pairs so that the [[line segment]]s determined by any pair do not intersect any of the given four lines except at the endpoints. These three line segments are called [[diagonal]]s of the complete quadrilateral.
===Existence of the Newton−Gauss line=== [[File:Labeling for a complete quadrilateral.svg|right|350px|Labels used in proof concerning complete quadrilateral]] It is a well-known theorem that the three midpoints of the diagonals of a complete quadrilateral are [[collinear]].<ref name=Johson62>{{harvnb|Johnson|2007|loc=p. 62}}</ref> There are several proofs of the result based on areas <ref name=Johson62 /> or wedge products<ref>{{citation|first=Dan|last=Pedoe|title=Geometry A Comprehensive Course|year=1988|origyear=1970|publisher=Dover|pages=46–47|isbn=0-486-65812-0}}</ref> or, as the following proof, on [[Menelaus's theorem]], due to Hillyer and published in 1920.<ref>{{harvnb|Johnson|2007|loc=p. 152}}</ref>
Let the complete quadrilateral {{math|''ABCA'B'C' ''}} be labeled as in the diagram with diagonals {{math|''AA' ''}}, {{math|''BB' ''}} and {{math|''CC' ''}} and their respective midpoints, {{mvar|L}}, {{mvar|M}} and {{mvar|N}}. Let the midpoints of {{mvar|BC}}, {{mvar|CA'}} and {{mvar|A'B}} be {{mvar|P}}, {{mvar|Q}} and {{mvar|R}} respectively. Using similar triangles it is seen that {{mvar|QR}} intersects {{mvar|AA'}} at {{mvar|L}}, {{mvar|RP}} intersects {{mvar|BB'}} at {{mvar|M}} and {{mvar|PQ}} intersects {{mvar|CC'}} at {{mvar|N}}. Again, similar triangles provide the following proportions, :<math>\frac{RL}{LQ} = \frac{BA}{AC}, \quad \frac{QN}{NP} = \frac{A'C'}{C'B}, \quad \frac{PM}{MR} = \frac{CB'}{B'A'}. </math> However, the line {{mvar|AB'C'}} intersects the sides of triangle {{mvar|A'BC}}, so by Menelaus's theorem the product of the terms on the right hand sides is −1. Thus, the product of the terms on the left hand sides is also −1 and again by Menelaus's theorem, the points {{mvar|L}}, {{mvar|M}} and {{mvar|N}} are collinear on the sides of triangle {{mvar|PQR}}.
== Applications to cyclic quadrilaterals==
The following are some results that use the Newton–Gauss line of complete quadrilaterals that are associated with [[cyclic quadrilateral]]s, based on the work of Barbu and Patrascu.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://forumgeom.fau.edu/FG2012volume12/FG201212.pdf|title=Some Properties of the Newton–Gauss Line|last=Patrascu|first=Ion|date=|website=Forum Geometricorum|access-date=29 April 2019}}</ref>
=== Equal angles === [[File:Newton-Gauss_Line_Figure_1_subtext.png|thumb|''Figure 1:'' An angle equality.]]
Given any cyclic quadrilateral <math>ABCD</math>, let point <math>F</math> be the [[Line–line intersection|point of intersection]] between the two diagonals <math>AC</math> and <math>BD</math>. Extend the diagonals <math>AB</math> and <math>CD</math> until they meet at the point of intersection, <math>E</math>. Let the [[midpoint]] of the [[Line segment|segment]] <math>EF</math> be <math>N</math>, and let the midpoint of the segment <math>BC</math> be <math>M</math> (Figure 1).
==== Theorem ==== If the midpoint of the line segment <math>BF</math> is <math>P</math>, the Newton–Gauss line of the complete quadrilateral <math>ABCDEF</math> and the line <math>PM</math> determine an angle <math>\angle PMN</math> equal to <math>\angle EFD</math>.
===== Proof ===== First show that the [[triangle]]s <math>\triangle NPM</math> and <math>\triangle EDF</math> are [[Similarity (geometry)|similar]].
Since <math>BE \parallel PN</math> and <math>FC \parallel PM</math>, we know <math>\angle NPM = \angle EAC</math>. Also, <math>\left ( \frac{BE}{PN} \right )</math><math>= \left ( \frac{FC}{PM} \right ) = 2.</math>
In the cyclic quadrilateral <math>ABCD</math>, these [[Equality (mathematics)|equalities]] hold:
<math>\angle EDF = \angle ADF + \angle EDA = \angle ACB + \angle ABC = \angle EAC.</math>
Therefore, <math>\angle NPM = \angle EDF.</math>
Let <math>R_1</math> and <math>R_2</math> be the [[Radius|radii]] of the [[Circumscribed circle|circumcircles]] of <math>\triangle EDB</math> and <math>\triangle FCD</math>, respectively. Apply the [[law of sines]] to the triangles, to obtain:
: <math>\frac {BE}{FC}=\frac {2R_1\sin EDB}{2R_2\sin FDC}=\frac {R_1}{R_2}=\frac {2R_1\sin EBD}{2R_2\sin FCD} = \frac{DE}{DF}.</math>
Since <math>BE = 2PN</math>and <math>FC = 2PM</math>, this shows the equality <math>\frac{PN}{PM} = \frac{DE}{DF}.</math> The similarity of triangles <math>PMN</math> and <math>DFE</math> follows, and <math>\angle NMP = \angle EFD.</math>
===== Remark ===== If <math>Q</math> is the midpoint of the line segment <math>FC</math>, it follows by the same reasoning that <math>\angle NMQ = \angle EFA.</math> [[File:Newton-Gauss_Line_Figure_2_Subtext.png|thumb|''Figure 2:'' Isogonal lines.]]
=== Isogonal lines === ==== Theorem ==== The line through <math>E</math> [[Parallel (geometry)|parallel]] to the Newton–Gauss line of the complete quadrilateral <math>ABCDEF</math> and the line <math>EF</math> are isogonal lines of <math>\angle BEC</math>, that is, each line is a [[Reflection (mathematics)|reflection]] of the other about the [[angle bisector]].<ref name=":2" /> (Figure 2)
===== Proof ===== Triangles <math>EDF</math> and <math>NPM</math> are similar by the above argument, so <math>\angle DEF = \angle PNM</math>. Let <math>E'</math> be the point of intersection of <math>BC</math> and the line parallel to the Newton–Gauss line <math>NM</math> through <math>E</math>.
Since <math>PN||BE</math> and <math>NM||EE'</math>, <math>\angle BEF = \angle PNF</math>, and <math>\angle FNM = \angle E'EF</math>.
Therefore, <math>\angle CEE' = \angle DEF - \angle E'EF = \angle PNM - \angle FNM = \angle PNF = \angle BEF.</math>
=== Two cyclic quadrilaterals sharing a Newton-Gauss line===
[[File:Newton-Gauss_Line_Subtext_3.1.png|thumb|''Figure 3:'' Showing that the quadrilaterals '''''MPGN''''' and '''''MQHN''''' are cyclic.]]
==== Lemma ==== Let <math>G</math> and <math>H</math> be the [[Projection (linear algebra)|orthogonal projections]] of the point <math>F</math> on the lines <math>AB</math> and <math>CD</math> respectively.
The [[quadrilateral]]s <math>MPGN</math> and <math>MQHN</math>are cyclic quadrilaterals.<ref name=":2" />
===== Proof ===== <math>\angle EFD = \angle PMN</math>, as previously shown. The points <math>P</math> and <math>N</math> are the respective [[Circumscribed circle|circumcenters]] of the [[right triangle]]s <math>\triangle BFG</math> and <math>\triangle EFG</math>. Thus, <math>\angle PGF = \angle PFG</math> and <math>\angle FGN = \angle GFN</math>.
Therefore,
: <math>\begin{align} \angle PGN + \angle PMN & = (\angle PGF + \angle FGN) + \angle PMN \\[4pt] & = \angle PFG + \angle GFN + \angle EFD \\[4pt] &= 180^\circ \end{align}. </math>
Therefore, <math>MPGN</math> is a cyclic quadrilateral, and by the same reasoning, <math>MQHN</math> also lies on a circle.
[[File:Newton-Gauss_Line_Figure_3_subtext_2.png|thumb|''Figure 4:'' Showing that the complete quadrilaterals '''''EDGHIJ''''' and '''''ABCDEF''''' have the same Newton–Gauss line.]]
==== Theorem ==== Extend the lines <math>GF</math> and <math>HF</math> to intersect <math>EC</math> and <math>EB</math> at <math>I</math> and <math>J</math> respectively (Figure 4).
The complete quadrilaterals <math>EFGHIJ</math> and <math>ABCDEF</math> have the same Newton–Gauss line.<ref name=":2" />
===== Proof ===== The two complete quadrilaterals have a shared diagonal, <math>EF</math>. <math>N</math> lies on the Newton–Gauss line of both quadrilaterals. <math>N</math> is [[equidistant]] from <math>G</math> and <math>H</math>, since it is the [[Circumscribed circle|circumcenter]] of the cyclic quadrilateral <math>EGFH</math>.
If triangles <math>\triangle GMP</math> and <math>\triangle HMQ</math> are [[Congruence (geometry)|congruent]], and it will follow that <math>M</math> lies on the [[perpendicular bisector]] of the line <math>HG</math>. Therefore, the line <math>MN</math> contains the midpoint of <math>GH</math>, and is the Newton–Gauss line of <math>EFGHIJ</math>.
To show that the triangles <math>\triangle GMP</math> and <math>\triangle HMQ</math> are congruent, first observe that <math>PMQF</math> is a [[parallelogram]], since the points <math>M</math> and <math>P</math> are midpoints of <math>BF</math> and <math>BC</math> respectively.
Therefore,
* <math>MP = QF = HQ,</math> * <math>GP = PF = MQ,</math> and * <math>\angle MPF = \angle FQM.</math>
Also note that
: <math>\angle FPG = 2 \angle PBG = 2 \angle DBA = 2 \angle DCA = 2 \angle HCF = \angle HQF.</math>
Hence,
: <math>\angle MPG = \angle MPF + \angle FPG = \angle FQM + \angle HQF = \angle HQF + \angle FQM = \angle HQM.</math>
Therefore, <math>\triangle GMP</math> and <math>\triangle HMQ</math> are congruent by SAS.
===== Remark ===== Due to <math>\triangle GMP</math> and <math>\triangle HMQ</math> being congruent triangles, their [[Circumscribed circle|circumcircles]] <math>MPGN</math> and <math>MQHN</math> are also [[Congruence (geometry)|congruent]].
== History == The Newton–Gauss line proof was developed by the two mathematicians it is named after: [[Isaac Newton|Sir Isaac Newton]] and [[Carl Friedrich Gauss]].{{citation needed|date=June 2019}} The initial framework for this theorem is from the work of [[Isaac Newton|Newton]], in his previous theorem on the Newton line, in which Newton showed that the center of a conic inscribed in a quadrilateral lies on the Newton–Gauss line.<ref>{{citation|first=David|last=Wells|title=The Penguin Dictionary of Curious and Interesting Geometry|year=1991|publisher=Penguin Books|page=[https://archive.org/details/penguindictionar0000well/page/36 36]|isbn=978-0-14-011813-1|url=https://archive.org/details/penguindictionar0000well/page/36}}</ref>
The theorem of Gauss and Bodenmiller states that the three circles whose diameters are the diagonals of a complete quadrilateral are [[Coaxal circles|coaxal]].<ref>{{harvnb|Johnson|2007|loc=p. 172}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *{{citation|first=Roger A.|last=Johnson|title=Advanced Euclidean Geometry|publisher=Dover|year=2007|origyear=1929|isbn=978-0-486-46237-0}} **(available on-line as) {{Cite web|url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=wu.89043163211;view=1up;seq=14|title=Modern Geometry: An Elementary Treatise on the Geometry of the Triangle and the Circle|last=Johnson|first=Roger A.|date=1929|website=HathiTrust|access-date=28 May 2019}}
==External links== *{{Cite web|url=https://www.cut-the-knot.org/Curriculum/Geometry/Quadri.shtml#explanation|title=Theorem of Complete Quadrilateral: What is it?|last=Bogomonly|first=Alexander|access-date=11 May 2019}}

In mathematics, the '''categorical trace''' is a generalization of the [[trace (linear algebra)|trace]] of a matrix.
==Definition== The trace is defined in the context of a [[symmetric monoidal category]] ''C'', i.e., a category equipped with a suitable notion of a product <math>\otimes</math>. (The notation reflects that the product is, in many cases, a kind of a tensor product.) An object ''X'' in such a category ''C'' is called [[dualizable object|dualizable]] if there is another object <math>X^\vee</math> playing the rôle of a dual object of ''X''. In this situation, the trace of a morphism <math>f: X \to X</math> is defined as the compositition of the following morphisms: <math>\mathrm{tr}(f) : 1 \to X \otimes X^\vee \stackrel{f \otimes id} \to X \otimes X^\vee \to 1</math> where 1 is the monoidal unit and the extremal morphisms are the coevaluation and evaluation, which are part of the definition of dualizable objects.<ref>{{harvtxt|Ponto|Shulman|2014|loc=Def. 2.2}}</ref>
The same definition applies, to great effect, also when ''C'' is a symmetric monoidal ∞-category.
==Examples== If ''C'' is the category of vector spaces over a fixed field ''k'', the dualizable objects are precisely the finite-dimensional vector spaces, and the trace in the sense above is the morphism :<math>k \to k</math> which is the multiplication by the trace of the endomorphism ''f'' in the usual sense of linear algebra. In this sense, the categorical trace generalizes the linear-algebraic trace.
If ''C'' is the ∞-category of [[chain complex]]es of modules (over a fixed commutative ring ''R''), dualizable objects ''V'' in ''C'' are precisely the [[perfect complex]]es. The trace in this setting captures, for example, the [[Euler characteristic]], which is the alternating sum of the ranks of its terms: :<math>\mathrm{tr}(id_V) = \sum_i (-1)^i \operatorname {rank} V_i.</math><ref>{{harvtxt|Ponto|Shulman|2014|loc=Ex. 3.3}}</ref>
==Further applications==
{{harvtxt|Kondyrev|Prikhodko|2018}} have used categorical trace methods to prove an algebro-geometric version of the [[Atiyah–Bott fixed point formula]], an extension of the [[Lefschetz fixed point formula]].
==References==

{{about|the specific string game, Cat's cradle|string figures and games in general|string figure}} {{Other uses}} {{More citations needed|date=September 2017}} [[File:Cats-cradle.svg|thumb|185x185px|"Cradle", the first (and opening) position of Cat's cradle]] [[File:String Figures and How to Make Them.djvu|thumb|page=377|"Cat's eye to fish in a dish" illustration from Jayne (1906)]] '''Cat's cradle''' is one of the oldest games in recorded human history, and involves creating various [[string figure]]s, either individually or by passing a loop of string back and forth between two or more players. The true origin of the name is debated, though the first known reference is in ''The light of nature pursued'' by [[Abraham Tucker]] in 1768.{{Cite web|url=https://www.phrases.org.uk/meanings/87650.html|title='Cat's Cradle' - the meaning and origin of this phrase|last=Martin|first=Gary|website=Phrasefinder|language=en|access-date=2018-01-16}} The type of string, the specific figures, their order, and the names of the figures vary. Independent versions of this game have been found in [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous]] cultures throughout the world, including in Africa, Eastern Asia, the Pacific Islands, Australia, the Americas, and the Arctic.{{Cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/cats-cradle_us_5a3bcd4ae4b0df0de8b062f5|title=Cat's Cradle|last=Zgheib|first=Yara|date=2017-12-21|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2018-01-16}}{{Cite web|url=http://si-siris.blogspot.com/2010/05/cats-cradle.html|title=Cat's Cradle|last=Archives|first=National Anthropological|date=2010-05-13|website=Smithsonian Collections Blog|access-date=2018-01-16}} ==Play== [[File:Eishosai Choki - Cat's Cradle.jpg|thumb|''The lovers, Okiku and Yosuke, play cat’s cradle'', by [[Eishōsai Chōki]] (1804)]] The game consists of two or more players making a sequence of string figures, each altering the figure made by the previous player. The game begins with one player making the eponymous figure ''Cat's Cradle'' (above). After each figure, the next player manipulates that figure and removes the string figure from the hands of the previous player with one of a few simple motions and tightens the loop to create another figure, for example, ''Diamonds''. ''Diamonds'' might then lead to ''Candles'', for example, and then ''Manger''—an inverted ''Cat's Cradle''—and so on. Most of the core figures allow a choice between two or more subsequent figures: for example, ''Fish in a Dish'' can become ''Cat's Eye'' or ''Manger''. The game ends when a player makes a mistake or creates a dead-end figure, such as ''Two Crowns'', which cannot be turned into anything else.[[Camilla Gryski|Gryski, Camilla]] (1984). ''Cat's Cradle, Owl's Eyes: A Book of String Games''. Tom Sankey, illustrator. {{ISBN|0688039413}}. The game also may be played solo, as is done in Japan.Gryski, Camilla (1985). ''Many Stars & More String Games'', pp. 66–72. Tom Sankey, illustrator. {{ISBN|0-688-05792-6}}. ==History== [[File:Mma two young women seated by a kotatsu playing cats cradle 55802.jpg|thumb|"Two Young Women Seated by a [[Kotatsu]] Playing Cat's Cradle", [[Suzuki Harunobu]], ca. 1765]] The origin of the name "cat's cradle" is debated but the first known reference is in ''The light of nature pursued'' by [[Abraham Tucker]] in 1768.
"An ingenious play they call cat's cradle; one ties the two ends of a packthread together, and then winds it about his fingers, another with both hands takes it off perhaps in the shape of a gridiron, the first takes it from him again in another form, and so on alternately changing the packthread into a multitude of figures whose names I forget, it being so many years since I played at it myself."
The name may have come from a corruption of cratch-cradle, or [[manger]] [[bassinet|cradle]]{{#tag:ref|"Nares, under Cratche, an archaic word for manger, deems it to be the origin of the name of this game, which, however, he calls ''scratch-cradle''. But it clearly, he says, meant originally ''cratch-cradle,'' the manger which held the Holy Infant as a cradle..."Taylor, E.S. "Cats-Cradle", pp. 412–422 of ''Notes and Queries: A Medium of Inter-communication for Literary Men, Artists, Antiquaries, Genealogists, Etc.'', pp. 421–422, Vol. 11 (January—June, 1855). London: George Bell (1855).|group="nb"}}{{#tag:ref|"This opens to us the meaning of a childish game, corruptly called ''scratch-cradle,'' which consists in winding a packthread double round the hands, into a rude representation of a manger, which is taken off by the other player on his hands, so as to assume a new form, and thus alternately for several times, always changing the appearance. The art consists in making the right changes. But it clearly meant originally the ''cratch-cradle;'' the manger that held the Holy Infant as a cradle."Nares, Robert. ''A Glossary: Or, Collection of Words, Phrases, Names, and Allusions to Customs, Proverbs, Etc.'', p. 203. London: Gibbings and Company, Limited (1901).|group="nb"}} (although this derivation is disputed by the [[Oxford English Dictionary|OED]]). The connection between the two words, ''cratches'' and ''cradle'', may come from the Christian [[Nativity of Jesus|story of the birth of Jesus]], in which a manger is used as a cradle. In an 1858 ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]'' cartoon"[http://www.john-leech-archive.org.uk/1858/snowed-up.htm Snowed Up]", ''John-Leech-Archive.org.UK''. it is referred to as "scratch cradle", a name supported by [[E. Cobham Brewer|Brewer]]'s 1898 ''[[Brewer's Dictionary of Phrase and Fable|Dictionary]]''."[http://www.bartleby.com/81/15032.html Scratch Cradle]", ''Bartleby.com''. As "Cat's cradle" often is used to refer to string figures and games in general, Jayne uses "Real Cat's-Cradle" to refer to the specific game.{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/stringfigureshow0000jayn/page/324|url-access=registration|author=Jayne, C. F.|authorlink=Caroline Furness Jayne|year=1906|title=String Figures and How to Make Them|page=[https://archive.org/details/stringfigureshow0000jayn/page/324 324]|isbn=978-0-486-20152-8|publisher=[[Charles Scribner's Sons]]|place=New York}} Different [[culture]]s have different names for the game, and often different names for the individual figures. The [[French language|French]] word for manger is ''crèche'', and cattle feed racks are still known as ''cratches''. In [[Russia]] the whole game is called simply, ''the game of string'', and the ''diamonds'' pattern is called ''carpet'', with other pattern names such as ''field'', ''fish'', and ''sawhorse'' for the other figures—a ''cat'' isn't mentioned.Buchanan, Andrea J. and Peskowitz, Miriam (2007). ''The Daring Book for Girls'', p.277. {{ISBN|978-0-06-147257-2}}. The game may have originated in China.(1989). ''Anthroquest: the L.S.B. Leakey Foundation news'', Issues 39–46, p.17. The Foundation. In [[China]] the game is called ''fan sheng'' ({{lang-en|turning rope}}), or catch cradle. In some regions of the [[United States|U.S.]], this game also is known as ''Jack in the Pulpit''.Anderson, John P. (2010). ''Joyce's Finnegans Wake: The Curse of Kabbalah'', Volume 4, p.301. {{ISBN|978-1-59942-810-9}}. ==World records== Geneva Hultenius, Maryann Divona, and Rita Divona completed 21,200 changes of cat's cradles in 21 hours in Chula Vista, California between August 17–18, 1974. The ''[[Guinness World Records|Guinness Book of World Records]]'' reported it as a world record in the 1975 and 1976 editions.McWhirter, Norris and McWhirter, Alan Ross (1975). ''Guinness Book of World Records, 1976'', p.459. Revised. {{ISBN|978-0-8069-0014-8}}. Jane Muir and Robyn Lawrick completed 22,700 changes of cat's cradles in 21 hours at [[Market Mall|Calgary Market Mall]], Alberta, Canada on August 25, 1976.McWhirter, Ross (1983). ''Guinness Book of World Records 1979'', p.453. {{ISBN|978-0-8069-0130-5}}. ==See also== *[[List of string figures]] ==Notes== ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Cat's cradle}} * "[http://www.stringfigures.info/cfj/real-cats-cradle.html Directions for play by C.F. Jayne]", a digital version of C.F. Jayne's 1906 compendium, featuring many other string figures. * "[http://www.alysion.org/figures/catcradle.htm Directions for play at Alysion.org]" * "[http://www.ifyoulovetoread.com/book/chten_cats1105.htm Directions for play at IfYouLoveToRead.com]" * "[http://www.wikihow.com/Play-The-Cat%27s-Cradle-Game Directions for play at wikihow.com]", a high-bandwidth page with videos for each of the different steps of the game. * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VpHTPnrYLzQ How to do Cat's Cradle], MomsMinivan, video, August 7, 2013, with a link to written instructions. {{Library resources box}} {{Hand games}} {{String figures}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cat's Cradle}} [[Category:String figures]] [[Category:Geometry]] [[Category:Ropework]]

In geometry, the '''inverse Pythagorean theorem''' is as follows:<ref>Johan Wästlund, "Summing inverse squares by euclidean geometry", http://www.math.chalmers.se/~wastlund/Cosmic.pdf, pp. 4–5.</ref>
: Let ''A'', ''B'' be the endpoints of the hypotenuse of a right triangle ''ABC''. Let ''D'' be the foot of a perpendicular dropped from ''C'', the vertex of the right angle, to the hypotenuse. Then :: <math> \frac 1 {CD^2} = \frac 1 {AC^2} + \frac 1 {BC^2}. </math>

In [[geometry]], a '''valuation''' is a finitely additive function on a collection of admissible subsets of a fixed set <math>X</math> with values in an abelian [[semigroup]]. For example, the [[Lebesgue measure]] is a valuation on finite unions of convex bodies (i.e. non-empty compact convex sets) of Euclidean space <math>\mathbb R^n</math>. Other examples of valuations on finite unions of convex bodies are the surface area, the mean width, and the [[Euler characteristic]].
In the geometric setting, often continuity (or smoothness) conditions are imposed on valuations, but there are also purely discrete facets of the theory. In fact, the concept of valuation has its origin in the dissection theory of [[polytope]]s and in particular [[Hilbert's third problem]], which has grown into a rich theory, heavily reliant on advanced tools from abstract algebra.
==Definition== Let <math>X</math> be a set and <math>\mathcal S</math> be a collection of admissible subsets of <math>X</math>. A function <math>\phi</math> on <math>\mathcal S</math> with values in an abelian semigroup <math>R</math> is called a '''valuation''' if it satisfies <math display="block"> \phi(A\cup B)+ \phi(A\cap B) = \phi(A)+ \phi(B)</math> whenever <math>A</math>, <math>B</math>, <math>A\cup B</math>, and <math>A\cap B</math> are elements of <math>\mathcal S</math>. If <math>\emptyset\in \mathcal S</math>, then one always assumes <math>\phi(\emptyset)=0</math>.
===Examples=== Some common examples for the admissible sets <math>\mathcal S</math> are non-empty compact convex sets (convex bodies) in <math>\mathbb R^n</math>, compact convex polytopes in <math>\mathbb R^n</math>, convex cones, and smooth compact polyhedra in a smooth manifold <math>X</math>.
Let <math>V</math> be a finite-dimensional vector space over <math>\mathbb R</math>, and let <math>\mathcal K(V)</math> denote the set of convex bodies in <math>V</math>.
* The [[Euler characteristic]] <math>\chi(K)=1</math> is a valuation on <math>\mathcal K(V)</math>, and it extends as a valuation to the collection of finite unions of convex bodies. * Any [[Lebesgue measure]] on <math>V</math>, restricted to convex bodies, is a valuation on <math>\mathcal K(V)</math>. * Among the valuations derived from volume are the [[Mixed volume#Quermassintegrals|intrinsic volumes]], <math display="block"> V_i(K)= c_{n,i} \left.\frac{d^i}{dt^i}\right|_{t=0} \operatorname{vol}_n(K+tB^n),\qquad i=0,1,\ldots,n,</math> where <math>c_{n,i}</math> is a normalizing constant and <math>B^n\subset \mathbb R^n</math> is the Euclidean unit ball, and more generally the [[mixed volume]]s (with some entries fixed arbitrarily). * The lattice point enumerator <math>G(P)= |\mathbb Z^n\cap P|</math>, where <math>\mathbb Z^n\subset \mathbb R^n</math> is the integer lattice, is a valuation on lattice polytopes. * The map <math>K\mapsto h_K</math>, where <math display="block">h_K(\xi) = \sup_{x\in K} \xi(x) \qquad \text{for } \xi\in V^*,</math> is the [[support function]] of <math>K</math>, is a valuation on <math>\mathcal K(V)</math>.
==Valuations on convex bodies== A valuation on <math>\mathcal K(V)</math> is said to be ''translation invariant'' if <math>\phi(K+x)=\phi(K)</math> for all <math>x\in V</math> and all convex bodies <math>K</math>.
Let <math>K,L</math> be two convex bodies in <math>V</math>. After a choice of Euclidean inner product, their [[Hausdorff distance]] <math>d_H(K,L)</math> is defined by <math display="block"> d_H(K,L)= \inf\{\varepsilon >0\colon K\subset L_\varepsilon \text{ and } L\subset K_\varepsilon \},</math> where <math>K_\varepsilon</math> denotes the <math>\varepsilon</math>-neighborhood of <math>K</math>. Equipped with this metric, <math>\mathcal K(V)</math> is a locally compact space.
The space of continuous, translation-invariant valuations on <math>\mathcal K(V)</math> taking values in the complex numbers <math>\mathbb C</math>, is denoted by <math>\operatorname{Val}(V)</math>.
The topology on <math>\operatorname{Val}(V)</math> is the topology of uniform convergence on compact subsets of <math>\mathcal K (V)</math>. Equipped with the norm <math display="block"> \|\phi\| = \max\{ |\phi(K)|\colon K\subset B\},</math> where <math>B\subset V</math> is a bounded subset with nonempty interior, <math>\operatorname{Val}(V)</math> is a [[Banach space]].
===Homogeneous valuations=== A translation-invariant continuous valuation <math>\phi\in \operatorname{Val}(V)</math> is said to be ''<math>i</math>-homogeneous'' if <math display="block"> \phi(\lambda^i K)= \lambda^i\phi(K)</math> for all <math>\lambda>0</math> and <math>K\in \mathcal K(V)</math>. The subset <math>\operatorname{Val}_i(V)</math> of <math>i</math>-homogeneous valuations is a vector subspace of <math>\operatorname{Val}(V)</math>. [[Peter McMullen|McMullen's]] decomposition theorem<ref name="McMullen"> P. McMullen, ''Continuous translation-invariant valuations on the space of compact convex sets'', Arch. Math. (Basel) '''34''' (1980), no. 4, 377-384</ref> states that
<math display="block"> \operatorname{Val}(V)= \bigoplus_{i=0}^n \operatorname{Val}_i(V), \qquad n=\dim V.</math>
In particular, the degree of a homogeneous valuation is always an integer between <math>0</math> and <math>n=\operatorname{dim} V</math>.
Valuations are not only graded by the degree of homogeneity, but also by the parity with respect to the reflection through the origin, namely <math display="block"> \operatorname{Val}_i = \operatorname{Val}_i^+ \oplus \operatorname{Val}_i^-,</math> where <math>\phi\in \operatorname{Val}_i^\epsilon</math> with <math>\epsilon \in \{+,-\}</math> if and only if <math>\phi(- K)= \epsilon \phi(K)</math> for all convex bodies <math>K</math>. The elements of <math>\operatorname{Val}_i^+</math> and <math>\operatorname{Val}_i^-</math> are said to be ''even'' and ''odd'', respectively.
It is a simple fact that <math>\operatorname{Val}_0(V)</math> is <math>1</math>-dimensional and spanned by the Euler characteristic <math>\chi</math>, i.e. consists of the constant valuations on <math>\mathcal K(V)</math>.
In 1957 [[Hugo Hadwiger|Hadwiger]]<ref name="Hadwiger">H. Hadwiger, ''Vorlesungen über Inhalt, Oberfläche und Isoperimetrie'', Springer-Verlag, Berlin-Göttingen-Heidelberg, 1957</ref> proved that <math>\operatorname{Val}_n(V)</math> (where <math>n=\dim V</math>) coincides with the <math>1</math>-dimensional space of Lebesgue measures on <math>V</math>.
A valuation <math>\phi\in \operatorname{Val}(\mathbb R^n)</math> is ''simple'' if <math>\phi(K)=0</math> for all convex bodies with <math>\dim K<n</math>. [[Rolf Schneider|Schneider]]<ref name="Schneider:Simple">R. Schneider, ''Simple valuations on convex bodies'', Mathematika '''43''' (1996), no. 1, 32-39.</ref> in 1996 described all simple valuations on <math>\mathbb R^n</math>: they are given by <math display="block">\phi(K)=c\operatorname{vol}(K)+\int_{S^{n-1}}f(\theta)d\sigma_K(\theta),</math> where <math>c\in\mathbb C</math>, <math>f\in C(S^{n-1})</math> is an arbitrary odd function on the unit sphere <math>S^{n-1}\subset \mathbb R^n</math>, and <math>\sigma_K</math> is the surface area measure of <math>K</math>. In particular, any simple valuation is the sum of an <math>n</math>- and an <math>(n-1)</math>-homogeneous valuation. This in turn implies that an <math>i</math>-homogeneous valuation is uniquely determined by its restrictions to all <math>(i+1)</math>-dimensional subspaces.
===Embedding theorems=== The Klain embedding is a linear injection of <math>\operatorname{Val}_i^+(V)</math>, the space of even <math>i</math>-homogeneous valuations, into the space of continuous sections of a canonical complex line bundle over the Grassmannian <math>\operatorname{Gr}_i(V)</math> of <math>i</math>-dimensional linear subspaces of <math>V</math>. Its construction is based on Hadwiger's characterization<ref name="Hadwiger" /> of <math>n</math>-homogeneous valuations. If <math>\phi\in \operatorname{Val}_i(V)</math> and <math>E\in \operatorname{Gr}_i(V)</math>, then the restriction <math>\phi|_E</math> is an element <math>\operatorname{Val}_i(E)</math>, and by Hadwiger's theorem it is a Lebesgue measure. Hence <math display="block">\operatorname{Kl}_\phi(E)= \phi|_E</math> defines a continuous section of the line bundle over <math>\operatorname{Gr}_i(V)</math> with fiber over <math>E</math> equal to the <math>1</math>-dimensional space <math>\operatorname{Dens}(E)</math> of [[Density on a manifold|densities]] (Lebesgue measures) on <math>E</math>.
'''Theorem''' (Klain<ref name="Klain">D. A. Klain, ''A short proof of Hadwiger's characterization theorem'', Mathematika 42 (1995), no. 2, 329-339.</ref>). The linear map <math>\operatorname{Kl}\colon \operatorname{Val}_i^+(V)\to C(\operatorname{Gr}_i(V),\operatorname{Dens}(E))</math> is injective.
A different injection, known as the Schneider embedding, exists for odd valuations. It is based on Schneider's description of simple valuations.<ref name="Schneider:Simple" /> It is a linear injection of <math>\operatorname{Val}_i^-(V)</math>, the space of odd <math>i</math>-homogeneous valuations, into a certain quotient of the space of continuous sections of a line bundle over the partial flag manifold of cooriented pairs <math>(F^i\subset E^{i+1})</math>. Its definition is reminiscent of the Klain embedding, but more involved. Details can be found in.<ref name="Alesker:Book">S. Alesker, ''Introduction to the theory of valuations''. CBMS Regional Conference Series in Mathematics, 126. Published for the Conference Board of the Mathematical Sciences, Washington, DC; by the American Mathematical Society, Providence, RI, 2018.</ref>
The Goodey-Weil embedding is a linear injection of <math>\operatorname{Val}_i</math> into the space of distributions on the <math>i</math>-fold product of the <math>(n-1)</math>-dimenionsal sphere. It is nothing but the [[Schwartz kernel theorem|Schwartz kernel]] of a natural polarization that any <math>\phi\in\operatorname{Val}_k(V)</math> admits, namely as a functional on the <math>k</math>-fold product of <math>C^2(S^{n-1})</math>, the latter space of functions having the geometric meaning of differences of support functions of smooth convex bodies. For details, see.<ref name="Alesker:Book" />
===Irreducibility Theorem=== The classical theorems of Hadwiger, Schneider and McMullen give fairly explicit descriptions of valuations that are homogeneous of degree <math>1</math>, <math>n-1</math>, and <math>n=\operatorname{dim} V</math>. But for degrees <math>1<i<n-1</math> very little was known before the turn of the 21st century. McMullen's conjecture is the statement that the valuations <math display="block">\phi_A(K)=\operatorname{vol}_n(K+A), \qquad A\in\mathcal K(V),</math> span a dense subspace of <math>\operatorname{Val}(V)</math>. McMullen's conjecture was confirmed by [[Semyon Alesker|Alesker]] in a much stronger form, which became known as the Irreducibility Theorem:
'''Theorem''' (Alesker<ref name="Alesker:Irred">S. Alesker, ''Description of translation invariant valuations on convex sets with solution of P. McMullen's conjecture''. Geom. Funct. Anal. '''11''' (2001), no. 2, 244–272.</ref>). For every <math>0\leq i\leq n</math>, the natural action of <math>GL(V)</math> on the spaces <math>\operatorname{Val}_i^+(V)</math> and <math>\operatorname{Val}_i^-(V)</math> is irreducible.
Here the action of the [[general linear group]] <math>GL(V)</math> on <math>\operatorname{Val}(V)</math> is given by <math display="block"> (g\cdot \phi)(K)= \phi(g^{-1} K).</math> The proof of the Irreducibility Theorem is based on the embedding theorems of the previous section and [[Beilinson-Bernstein localization]].
===Smooth valuations=== A valuation <math>\phi\in\operatorname{Val}(V)</math> is called ''smooth'' if the map <math>g\mapsto g\cdot \phi</math> from <math>GL(V)</math> to <math>\operatorname{Val}(V)</math> is smooth. In other words, <math>\phi</math> is smooth if and only if <math>\phi</math> is a smooth vector of the natural representation of <math>GL(V)</math> on <math>\operatorname{Val}(V)</math>. The space of smooth valuations <math>\operatorname{Val}^\infty(V)</math> is dense in <math>\operatorname{Val}(V)</math>; it comes equipped with a natural Fréchet-space topology, which is finer than the one induced from <math>\operatorname{Val}(V)</math>.
For every (complex-valued) smooth function <math>f</math> on <math>\operatorname{Gr}_i(\mathbb R^n)</math>, <math display="block" >\phi(K)=\int_{\operatorname{Gr}_i(\mathbb R^n)} \operatorname{vol}_i(P_E K) f(E) dE,</math> where <math>P_E\colon \mathbb R^n\to E</math> denotes the orthogonal projection and <math>dE</math> is the Haar measure, defines a smooth even valuation of degree <math>i</math>. It follows from the Irreducibility Theorem, in combination with the Casselman-Wallach theorem, that any smooth even valuation can be represented in this way. Such a representation is sometimes called a ''Crofton formula''.
For any (complex-valued) smooth [[differential form]] <math>\omega\in \Omega^{n-1}(\mathbb R^n\times S^{n-1})</math> that is invariant under all the translations <math>(x,u)\mapsto (x+t,u)</math> and every number <math>c\in \mathbb C</math>, integration over the ''normal cycle'' defines a smooth valuation: {{NumBlk|:|<math display="block"> \phi(K)= c\operatorname{vol}_n(K) + \int_{N(K)} \omega, \qquad K\in \mathcal K(\mathbb R^n). </math>|{{EquationRef|1}}}} As a set, the normal cycle <math>N(K)</math> consists of the outward unit normals to <math>K</math>. The Irreducibility Theorem implies that every smooth valuation is of this form.
==Operations on translation-invariant valuations== There are several natural operations defined on the subspace of smooth valuations <math>\operatorname{Val}^\infty(V)\subset \operatorname{Val}(V)</math>. The most important one is the product of two smooth valuations. Together with pullback and pushforward, this operation extends to valuations on manifolds.
===Exterior product=== Let <math>V,W</math> be finite-dimensional real vector spaces. There exists a bilinear map, called the exterior product, <math display="block"> \boxtimes \colon \operatorname{Val}^\infty(V)\times \operatorname{Val}^\infty(W)\to \operatorname{Val}(V\times W) </math> which is uniquely characterized by the following two properties: *it is continuous with respect to the usual topologies on <math>\operatorname{Val}</math> and <math>\operatorname{Val}^\infty</math>. * if <math>\phi=\operatorname{vol}_V(\bullet + A)</math> and <math>\psi= \operatorname{vol}_W(\bullet + B)</math> where <math>A\in \mathcal K(V)</math> and <math>B\in \mathcal K(W)</math> are convex bodies with smooth boundary and strictly positive Gauss curvature, and <math>\operatorname{vol}_V</math> and <math>\operatorname{vol}_W</math> are densities on <math>V</math> and <math>W</math>, then <math display="block"> \phi\boxtimes \psi = (\operatorname{vol}_V\boxtimes \operatorname{vol}_W) (\bullet + A\times B).</math>
===Product=== The product of two smooth valuations <math>\phi,\psi\in\operatorname{Val}^\infty (V)</math> is defined by <math display="block"> (\phi\cdot \psi)(K)= (\phi\boxtimes \psi)(\Delta(K)),</math> where <math>\Delta \colon V\to V\times V</math> is the diagonal embedding. The product is a continuous map <math display="block"> \operatorname{Val}^\infty (V) \times \operatorname{Val}^\infty (V) \to \operatorname{Val}^\infty (V) .</math> Equipped with this product, <math> \operatorname{Val}^\infty (V) </math> becomes a commutative associative graded algebra with the Euler characteristic as the multiplicative identity.
===Alesker-Poincaré duality=== By a theorem of Alesker, the restriction of the product <math display="block">\operatorname{Val}_k^\infty(V)\times \operatorname{Val}_{n-k}^\infty(V)\to \operatorname{Val}_n^\infty(V)=\operatorname{Dens}(V)</math> is a non-degenerate pairing. This motivates the definition of the <math>k</math>-homogeneous ''generalized valuation'', denoted <math>\operatorname{Val}_k^{-\infty}(V)</math>, as <math>\operatorname{Val}^\infty_{n-k}(V)^*\otimes\operatorname{Dens}(V)</math>, topologized with the weak topology. By the Alesker-Poincaré duality, there is a natural dense inclusion <math>\operatorname{Val}_k^\infty(V)\hookrightarrow\operatorname{Val}_k^{-\infty}(V)</math>.
===Convolution=== Convolution is a natural product on <math>\operatorname{Val}^\infty(V)\otimes \operatorname{Dens}(V^*)</math>. For simplicity, we fix a density <math>\operatorname{vol}</math> on <math>V</math> to trivialize the second factor. Define for fixed <math>A,B\in\mathcal K(V)</math> with smooth boundary and strictly positive Gauss curvature <math display="block">\operatorname{vol}(\bullet+A)\ast\operatorname{vol}(\bullet+B)=\operatorname{vol}(\bullet+A+B).</math> There is then a unique extension by continuity to a map <math display="block"> \operatorname{Val}^\infty (V) \times \operatorname{Val}^\infty (V) \to \operatorname{Val}^\infty (V),</math> called the convolution. Unlike the product, convolution respects the co-grading, namely if <math>\phi\in\operatorname{Val}^\infty_{n-i}(V)</math>, <math>\psi\in\operatorname{Val}^\infty_{n-j}(V)</math>, then <math>\phi\ast\psi\in \operatorname{Val}^\infty_{n-i-j}(V)</math>.
For instance, let <math>V(K_1,\ldots, K_n)</math> denote the mixed volume of the convex bodies <math>K_1,\ldots, K_n\subset \mathbb R^n</math>. If convex bodies <math>A_1,\dots,A_{n-i}</math> in <math>\mathbb R^n</math> with a smooth boundary and strictly positive Gauss curvature are fixed, then <math> \phi(K) = V(K[i], A_1,\dots,A_{n-i})</math> defines a smooth valuation of degree <math>i</math>. The convolution two such valuations is <math display="block">V(\bullet[i], A_1,\dots,A_{n-i})\ast V(\bullet[j],B_1,\dots,B_{n-j})=c_{i,j}V(\bullet[n-j-i], A_1,\dots,A_{n-i},B_1,\dots,B_{n-j}),</math> where <math>c_{i,j}</math> is a constant depending only on <math>i,j,n</math>.
===Fourier transform=== The Alesker-Fourier transform is a natural, <math>GL(V)</math>-equivariant isomorphism of complex-valued valuations <math display="block">\mathbb F: \operatorname{Val}^\infty(V)\to \operatorname{Val}^\infty(V^*)\otimes \operatorname{Dens}(V),</math> discovered by Alesker and enjoying many properties resembling the classical Fourier transform, which explains its name.
It reverses the grading, namely <math>\mathbb F: \operatorname{Val}_k^\infty(V)\to \operatorname{Val}^\infty_{n-k}(V^*)\otimes \operatorname{Dens}(V)</math>, and intertwines the product and the convolution: <math display="block">\mathbb F(\phi\cdot \psi)=\mathbb F\phi\ast\mathbb F\psi.</math>
Fixing for simplicity a Euclidean structure to identify <math>V=V^*</math>, <math>\operatorname{Dens}(V)=\mathbb C</math>, we have the identity <math display="block">\mathbb F^2\phi(K)=\phi(-K).</math> On even valuations, there is a simple description of the Fourier transform in terms of the Klain embedding: <math>\operatorname{Kl}_{\mathbb F\phi}(E)=\operatorname{Kl}_\phi(E^\perp)</math>. In particular, even real-valued valuations remain real-valued after the Fourier transform.
For odd valuations, the description of the Fourier transform is substantially more involved. Unlike the even case, it is no longer of purely geometric nature. For instance, the space of real-valued odd valuations is not preserved.
===Pullback and pushforward=== Given a linear map <math>f:U\to V</math>, there are induced operations of pullback <math>f^*:\operatorname{Val}(V)\to \operatorname{Val}(U)</math> and pushforward <math>f_*:\operatorname{Val}(U)\otimes\operatorname{Dens}(U)^*\to \operatorname{Val}(V)\otimes \operatorname{Dens}(V)^*</math>. The pullback is the simpler of the two, given by <math>f^*\phi(K)=\phi(f(K))</math>. It evidently preserves the parity and degree of homogeneity of a valuation. Note that the pullback does not preserve smoothness when <math>f</math> is not injective.
The pushforward is harder to define formally. For simplicity, fix Lebesgue measures on <math>U</math> and <math>V</math>. The pushforward can be uniquely characterized by describing its action on valuations of the form <math>\operatorname{vol}(\bullet+A)</math>, for all <math>A\in \mathcal K(U)</math>, and then extended by continuity to all valuations using the Irreducibility Theorem. For a surjective map <math>f</math>, <math display="block">f_*\operatorname{vol}(\bullet+A)=\operatorname{vol}(\bullet+f(A)).</math> For an inclusion <math>f:U\hookrightarrow V</math>, choose a splitting <math>V=U\oplus W</math>. Then <math display="block"> f_*\operatorname{vol}(\bullet + A) (K)= \int_{W}\operatorname{vol}(K\cap (U+w) + A) dw.</math> Informally, the pushforward is dual to the pullback with respect to the Alesker-Poincaré pairing: for <math>\phi\in \operatorname{Val}(V)</math> and <math>\psi\in\operatorname{Val}(U)\otimes\operatorname{Dens}(U)^*</math>, <math display="block">\langle f^*\phi,\psi\rangle =\langle \phi, f_*\psi\rangle.</math> However, this identity has to be carefully interpreted since the pairing is only well-defined for smooth valuations. For further details, see.<ref name="Alesker:Fourier">S. Alesker, ''A Fourier-type transform on translation-invariant valuations on convex sets''. Israel J. Math. '''181''' (2011), 189–294</ref>
==Valuations on manifolds== In a series of papers beginning in 2006, Alesker laid down the foundations for a theory of valuations on manifolds that extends the theory of valuations on convex bodies. The key observation leading to this extension is that via integration over the normal cycle ({{EquationNote|1}}), a smooth translation-invariant valuation may be evaluated on sets much more general than convex ones. Also ({{EquationNote|1}}) suggests to define smooth valuations in general by dropping the requirement that the form <math>\omega</math> be translation-invariant and by replacing the translation-invariant Lebesgue measure with an arbitrary smooth measure.
Let <math>X</math> be an n-dimensional smooth manifold and let <math>\mathbb P_X= \mathbb P_+(T^* X)</math> be the co-sphere bundle of <math>X</math>, i.e., the oriented projectivization of the cotangent bundle. Let <math>\mathcal P(X)</math> denote the collection of compact differentiable polyhedra in <math>X</math>. The normal cycle <math>N(A)\subset \mathbb P_X</math> of <math>A\in \mathcal P(X)</math>, which consists of the outward co-normals to <math>A</math>, is naturally a Lipschitz submanifold of dimension <math>n-1</math>.
For ease of presentation we henceforth assume that <math>X</math> is oriented, even though the concept of smooth valuations in fact does not depend on orientability. The space of smooth valuations <math>\mathcal V^\infty(X)</math> on <math>X</math> consists of functions <math>\phi\colon \mathcal P(X)\to \mathbb C</math> of the form <math display="block"> \phi(A)= \int_A\mu + \int_{N(A)}\omega,\qquad A\in \mathcal P(X),</math> where <math>\mu\in\Omega^n(X)</math> and <math>\omega\in \Omega^{n-1}(\mathbb P_X)</math> can be arbitrary. It was shown by Alesker that the smooth valuations on open subsets of <math>X</math> form a soft sheaf over <math>X</math>.
===Examples=== The following are examples of smooth valuations on a smooth manifold <math>X</math>: * Smooth measures on <math>X</math>. * The [[Euler characteristic]]; this follows from the work of [[Shiing-Shen Chern|Chern]]<ref>S.-S. Chern, ''On the curvatura integra in a Riemannian manifold''. Ann. of Math. (2) '''46''' (1945), 674–684.</ref> on the [[Gauss-Bonnet theorem]], where such <math>\mu</math> and <math>\omega</math> were constructed to represent the Euler characteristic. In particular, <math>\mu</math> is then the [[Chern–Gauss–Bonnet theorem|Chern-Gauss-Bonnet integrand]], which is the Pfaffian of the Riemannian curvature tensor. * If <math>X</math> is Riemannian, then the Lipschitz-Killing valuations or intrinsic volumes <math>V_0^X=\chi, V_1^X, \ldots, V_n^X=\mathrm{vol}_X</math> are smooth valuations. If <math>f\colon X\to \mathbb R^m</math> is any [[Embedding|isometric immersion]] into a Euclidean space, then <math> V_i^X= f^* V_i^{\mathbb R^m},</math> where <math>V_i^{\mathbb R^m}</math> denotes the usual intrinsic volumes on <math>\mathbb R^m</math> (see below for the definition of the pullback). The existence of these valuations is the essence of Weyl's tube formula.<ref>H. Weyl, ''On the Volume of Tubes''. Amer. J. Math. '''61''' (1939), no. 2, 461–472</ref> * Let <math>\mathbb C P^n</math> be the [[complex projective space]], and let <math>\mathrm{Gr}_k^\mathbb C</math> denote the Grassmannian of all complex projective subspaces of fixed dimension <math>k</math>. The function <math display="block">\phi(A) = \int_{\mathrm{Gr}_k^\mathbb C} \chi(A\cap E) dE, \qquad A\in \mathcal P (\mathbb C P^n),</math> where the integration is with respect to the Haar probability measure on <math>\mathrm{Gr}_k^\mathbb C</math>, is a smooth valuation. This follows from the work of Fu.<ref name="Fu:Kinematic">J. H. G. Fu, ''Kinematic formulas in integral geometry''. Indiana Univ. Math. J. '''39''' (1990), no. 4, 1115-1154</ref>
===Filtration=== The space <math>\mathcal V^\infty(X)</math> admits no natural grading in general, however it carries a canonical filtration <math display="block">\mathcal V^\infty(X)= W_0\supset W_1\supset \cdots \supset W_n.</math> Here <math>W_n</math> consists of the smooth measures on <math>X</math>, and <math>W_j</math> is given by forms <math>\omega</math> in the ideal generated by <math>\pi^*\Omega^j(X)</math>, where <math>\pi:\mathbb P_X\to X</math> is the canonical projection.
The associated graded vector space <math>\bigoplus_{i=0}^n W_i/W_{i+1}</math> is canonically isomorphic to the space of smooth sections <math display="block">\bigoplus_{i=0}^n C^\infty (X, \operatorname{Val}_i^\infty(TX)),</math> where <math>\operatorname{Val}_i^\infty(TX)</math> denotes the vector bundle over <math>X</math> such that the fiber over a point <math>x\in X</math> is <math>\operatorname{Val}_i^\infty(T_x X)</math>, the space of <math>i</math>-homogeneous smooth translation-invariant valuations on the tangent space <math>T_x X</math>.
===Product=== The space <math>\mathcal V^\infty(X)</math> admits a natural product. This product is continuous, commutative, associative, compatible with the filtration: <math display="block"> W_i\cdot W_j\subset W_{i+j},</math> and has the Euler characteristic as the identity element. It also commutes with the restriction to embedded submanifolds, and the diffeomorphism group of <math>X</math> acts on <math>\mathcal V^\infty(X)</math> by algebra automorphisms.
For example, if <math>X</math> is Riemannian, the Lipschitz-Killing valuations satisfy <math display="block"> V_i^X\cdot V_j^X= V_{i+j}^X.</math>
The Alesker-Poincaré duality still holds. For compact <math>X</math> it says that the pairing <math> \mathcal V^\infty(X)\times \mathcal V^\infty(X)\to \mathbb C</math>, <math>(\phi, \psi)\mapsto (\phi\cdot\psi) (X)</math> is non-degenerate. As in the translation-invariant case, this duality can be used to define generalized valuations. Unlike the translation-invariant case, no good definition of continuous valuations exists for valuations on manifolds.
The product of valuations closely reflects the geometric operation of intersection of subsets. Informally, consider the generalized valuation <math>\chi_A=\chi(A\cap\bullet)</math>. The product is given by <math>\chi_A\cdot\chi_B=\chi_{A\cap B}</math>. Now one can obtain smooth valuations by averaging generalized valuations of the form <math>\chi_A</math>, more precisely <math>\phi(X)=\int_S \chi_{s(A)}ds</math> is a smooth valuation if <math>S</math> is a sufficiently large measured family of diffeomorphisms. Then one has <math display="block">\int_S \chi_{s(A)}ds\cdot \int_{S'} \chi_{s'(B)}ds'=\int_{S\times S'} \chi_{s(A)\cap s'(B)}dsds',</math> see.<ref>J. H. G. Fu, ''Intersection theory and the Alesker product''. Indiana Univ. Math. J. '''65''' (2016), no. 4, 1347–1371. </ref>
===Pullback and pushforward=== Every smooth immersion <math>f\colon X\to Y</math> of smooth manifolds induces a pullback map <math>f^*\colon \mathcal V^\infty(Y) \to \mathcal V^\infty(X)</math>. If <math>f</math> is an embedding, then <math display="block"> (f^* \phi)(A) = \phi(f(A)), \qquad A\in\mathcal P (X).</math> The pullback is a morphism of filtered algebras. Every smooth proper submersion <math>f\colon X\to Y</math> defines a pushforward map <math>f^*\colon \mathcal V^\infty(X) \to \mathcal V^\infty(Y)</math> by <math display="block"> (f_* \phi)(A) = \phi(f^{-1}(A)), \qquad A\in\mathcal P (Y).</math> The pushforward is compatible with the filtration as well: <math>f_*:W_i(X)\to W_{i-(\dim X-\dim Y)}(Y)</math>. For general smooth maps, one can define pullback and pushforward for generalized valuations under some restrictions.
==Applications in Integral Geometry== Let <math>M</math> be a Riemannian manifold and let <math>G</math> be a Lie group of isometries of <math>M</math> acting transitively on the sphere bundle <math>SM</math>. Under these assumptions the space <math>\mathcal V^\infty(M)^G</math> of <math>G</math>-invariant smooth valuations on <math>M</math> is finite-dimensional; let <math>\phi_1, \ldots, \phi_m</math> be a basis. Let <math>A,B\in \mathcal P(M)</math> be differentiable polyhedra in <math>M</math>. Then integrals of the form <math>\int_G \phi_i(A\cap gB)dg </math> are expressible as linear combinations of <math>\phi_k(A)\phi_l(B)</math> with coefficients <math>c_i^{kl}</math> independent of <math>A</math> and <math>B</math>: {{NumBlk|:|<math display="block"> \int_G \phi_i(A\cap gB)dg = \sum_{k,l=1}^m c_i^{kl} \phi_k(A)\phi_l(B),\qquad A,B\in \mathcal P(M).</math>|{{EquationRef|2}}}} Formulas of this type are called ''kinematic formulas''. Their existence in this generality was proved by Fu.<ref name="Fu:Kinematic"/> For the three simply connected real space forms, i.e., the sphere, Euclidean space, and hyperbolic space, they go back to [[Wilhelm Blaschke|Blaschke]], [[Luis Santaló|Santaló]], [[Shiing-Shen Chern|Chern]], and [[Herbert Federer|Federer]].
Describing the kinematic formulas explicitly is typically a difficult problem. In fact already in the step from real to complex space forms, considerable difficulties arise and these have only recently been resolved by Bernig, Fu, and Solanes<ref>A. Bernig, J. H. G. Fu, G. Solanes, ''Integral geometry of complex space forms''. Geom. Funct. Anal. '''24''' (2014), no. 2, 403–492.</ref> <ref>A. Bernig, J. H. G. Fu, ''Hermitian integral geometry''. Ann. of Math. (2) '''173''' (2011), no. 2, 907–945.</ref> .The key insight responsible for this progress is that the kinematic formulas contain the same information as the algebra of invariant valuations <math>\mathcal V^\infty(M)^G</math>. For a precise statement, let <math display="block">k_G\colon \mathcal V^\infty(M)^G \to \mathcal V^\infty(M)^G\otimes \mathcal V^\infty(M)^G</math> be the kinematic operator, i.e., the map determined by the kinematic formulas ({{EquationNote|2}}). Let <math display="block">\operatorname{pd} \colon \mathcal V^\infty(M)^G \to \mathcal V^\infty(M)^{G*}</math> denote the Alesker-Poincaré duality, which is a linear isomorphism. Finally let <math>m_G^*</math> be the adjoint of the product map <math display="block">m_G\colon \mathcal V^\infty(M)^{G}\otimes \mathcal V^\infty(M)^{G} \to \mathcal V^\infty(M)^{G} . </math> The Fundamental theorem of algebraic integral geometry relating operations on valuations to integral geometry, states that if the Poincaré duality is used to identify <math>\mathcal V^\infty(M)^{G}</math> with <math>\mathcal V^\infty(M)^{G*}</math>, then <math>k_G=m_G^*</math>:
[[File:Fundamental theorem of algebraic integral geometry.svg|350px]].
