{{Notability|date=June 2020}}In [[mathematics]] and [[theoretical physics]], and especially [[gauge theory (mathematics)|gauge theory]], the '''deformed Hermitian Yang–Mills (dHYM) equation''' is a [[differential equation]] describing the [[equations of motion]] for a [[D-brane]] in the [[Topological string theory#B-model|B-model]] (commonly called a '''B-brane''') of [[string theory]]. The equation was derived by Mariño-Minasian-[[Greg Moore (physicist)|Moore]]-[[Andrew Strominger|Strominger]]<ref name=phys1>Marino, M., Minasian, R., Moore, G. and Strominger, A., 2000. Nonlinear instantons from supersymmetric p-branes. Journal of High Energy Physics, 2000(01), p.005.</ref> in the case of [[Abelian group|Abelian]] gauge group (the [[unitary group]] <math>\operatorname{U}(1)</math>), and by Leung-[[Shing-Tung Yau|Yau]]-[[Eric Zaslow|Zaslow]]<ref name=phys2>Leung, N.C., Yau, S.T. and Zaslow, E., 2000. From special lagrangian to hermitian-Yang-Mills via Fourier-Mukai transform. arXiv preprint math/0005118.</ref> using [[Mirror symmetry (string theory)|mirror symmetry]] from the corresponding equations of motion for D-branes in the [[Topological string theory#A-model|A-model]] of string theory.
== Definition ==
In this section we present the dHYM equation as explained in the mathematical literature by Collins-Xie-[[Shing-Tung Yau|Yau]].<ref name=col1>Collins, T.C., XIIE, D. and YAU, S.T.G., 2018. The Deformed Hermitian–Yang–Mills Equation in Geometry and Physics. Geometry and Physics: Volume 1: A Festschrift in Honour of Nigel Hitchin, 1, p.69.</ref> The deformed Hermitian–Yang–Mills equation is a fully non-linear partial differental equation for a [[Hermitian metric]] on a [[line bundle]] over a [[Compact space|compact]] [[Kähler manifold]], or more generally for a real [[Complex differential form|<math>(1,1)</math>-form]]. Namely, suppose <math>(X,\omega)</math> is a Kähler manifold and <math>[\alpha] \in H^{1,1}(X,\mathbb{R})</math> is a class. The case of a line bundle consists of setting <math>[\alpha]=c_1(L)</math> where <math>c_1(L)</math> is the first [[Chern class]] of a [[holomorphic line bundle]] <math>L\to X</math>. Suppose that <math>\dim X = n</math> and consider the topological constant :<math>\hat z([\omega], [\alpha]) = \int_X (\omega + i \alpha)^n.</math> Notice that <math>\hat z</math> depends only on the class of <math>\omega</math> and <math>\alpha</math>. Suppose that <math>\hat z\ne 0</math>. Then this is a complex number :<math>\hat z([\omega], [\alpha]) = r e^{i \theta}</math> for some real <math>r>0</math> and angle <math>\theta\in [0,2\pi)</math> which is uniquely determined.
Fix a smooth representative [[differential form]] <math>\alpha</math> in the class <math>[\alpha]</math>. For a smooth function <math>\phi: X \to \mathbb{R}</math> write <math>\alpha_{\phi} = \alpha + i \partial \bar \partial \phi</math>, and notice that <math>[\alpha_{\phi}] = [\alpha]</math>. The '''deformed Hermitian Yang–Mills equation''' for <math>(X,\omega)</math> with respect to <math>[\alpha]</math> is :<math>\begin{cases}\operatorname{Im}(e^{-i\theta} (\omega + i \alpha_{\phi})^n) = 0\\ \operatorname{Re}(e^{-i\theta} (\omega + i \alpha_{\phi})^n) > 0.\end{cases}</math>
The second condition should be seen as a [[Positive form|positivity]] condition on solutions to the first equation. That is, one looks for solutions to the equation <math>\operatorname{Im}(e^{-i\theta} (\omega + i \alpha_{\phi})^n) = 0</math> such that <math>\operatorname{Re}(e^{-i\theta} (\omega + i \alpha_{\phi})^n) > 0</math>. This is in analogy to the related problem of finding [[Kähler-Einstein metric]]s by looking for metrics <math>\omega + i \partial \bar \partial \phi</math> solving the Einstein equation, subject to the condition that <math>\phi</math> is a Kähler potential (which is a positivity condition on the form <math>\omega + i \partial \bar \partial \phi</math>).
== Discussion ==
=== Relation to Hermitian Yang–Mills equation ===
The dHYM equations can be transformed in several ways to illuminate several key properties of the equations. First, simple algebraic manipulation shows that the dHYM equation may be equivalently written :<math>\operatorname{Im}((\omega+i\alpha)^n)=\tan \theta \operatorname{Re}((\omega+i\alpha)^n).</math> In this form, it is possible to see the relation between the dHYM equation and the regular [[Hermitian Yang–Mills equation]]. In particular, the dHYM equation should look like the regular HYM equation in the so-called large volume limit. Precisely, one replaces the Kähler form <math>\omega</math> by <math>k\omega</math> for a positive integer <math>k</math>, and allows <math>k\to \infty</math>. Notice that the phase <math>\theta_k</math> for <math>(X,k\omega,[\alpha])</math> depends on <math>k</math>. In fact, <math>\tan \theta_k = O(k^{-1})</math>, and we can expand :<math>(k\omega + i \alpha)^n = k^n \omega^n + i n k^{n-1} \omega^{n-1}\wedge \alpha + O(k^{n-2}).</math> Here we see that :<math>\operatorname{Re}((k\omega + i \alpha)^n) = k^n \omega^n + O(k^{n-2}),\quad \operatorname{Im}((k\omega + i \alpha)^n) = nk^{n-1} \omega^{n-1}\wedge \alpha + O(k^{n-3}),</math> and we see the dHYM equation for <math>k\omega</math> takes the form :<math>C k^{n-1} \omega^n + O(k^{n-3}) = n k^{n-1} \omega^{n-1} \wedge \alpha + O(k^{n-3})</math> for some topological constant <math>C</math> determined by <math>\tan \theta</math>. Thus we see the leading order term in the dHYM equation is :<math>n\omega^{n-1}\wedge \alpha = C \omega^n</math> which is just the HYM equation (replacing <math>\alpha</math> by <math>F(h)</math> if necessary).
=== Local form ===
The dHYM equation may also be written in local coordinates. Fix <math>p\in X</math> and holomorphic coordinates <math>(z^1,\dots,z^n)</math> such that at the point <math>p</math>, we have :<math>\omega = \sum_{j=1}^n i dz^j \wedge d\bar z^j,\quad \alpha = \sum_{j=1}^n \lambda_j i dz^j \wedge d\bar z^j.</math> Here <math>\lambda_j \in \mathbb{R}</math> for all <math>j</math> as we assumed <math>\alpha</math> was a real form. Define the '''Lagrangian phase operator''' to be :<math>\Theta_{\omega}(\alpha) = \sum_{j=1}^n \arctan(\lambda_j).</math> Then simple computation shows that the dHYM equation in these local coordinates takes the form :<math>\Theta_{\omega}(\alpha) = \phi</math> where <math>\phi = \theta\mod 2\pi</math>. In this form one sees that the dHYM equation is fully non-linear and elliptic.
== Solutions ==
It is possible to use [[algebraic geometry]] to study the existence of solutions to the dHYM equation, as demonstrated by the work of Collins-Jacob-Yau and Collins-Yau.<ref name=coljacyau>Collins, T.C., Jacob, A. and Yau, S.T., 2015. (1, 1) forms with specified Lagrangian phase: a priori estimates and algebraic obstructions. arXiv preprint arXiv:1508.01934.</ref><ref name=colyau>Collins, T.C. and Yau, S.T., 2018. Moment maps, nonlinear PDE, and stability in mirror symmetry. arXiv preprint arXiv:1811.04824.</ref><ref name=colshi>Collins, T.C. and Shi, Y., 2020. Stability and the deformed Hermitian-Yang-Mills equation. arXiv preprint arXiv:2004.04831.</ref> Suppose that <math>V\subset X</math> is any analytic subvariety of dimension <math>p</math>. Define the '''central charge''' <math>Z_V([\alpha])</math> by :<math>Z_V([\alpha]) = -\int_V e^{-i\omega + \alpha}.</math> When the dimension of <math>X</math> is 2, Collins-Jacob-Yau show that if <math>\operatorname{Im}(Z_X([\alpha]))>0</math>, then there exists a solution of the dHYM equation in the class <math>[\alpha]\in H^{1,1}(X,\mathbb{R})</math> if and only if for every curve <math>C\subset X</math> we have :<math>\operatorname{Im}\left(\frac{Z_C([\alpha])}{Z_X([\alpha])}\right)>0.</math><ref name=coljacyau /> In the specific example where <math>X=\operatorname{Bl}_p \mathbb{CP}^n</math>, the [[blowing up|blow-up]] of [[complex projective space]], Jacob-Sheu show that <math>[\alpha]</math> admits a solution to the dHYM equation if and only if <math>Z_X([\alpha])\ne 0</math> and for any <math>V\subset X</math>, we similarly have :<math>\operatorname{Im}\left(\frac{Z_V([\alpha])}{Z_X([\alpha])}\right)>0.</math><ref name=jacsheu>A. Jacob, and N. Sheu, The deformed Hermitian-Yang-Mills equation on the blow-up of P n, in preparation</ref>
It has been shown by Gao Chen that in the so-called supercritical phase, where <math>\frac{(n-2)\pi}{2} < \theta < \frac{n\pi}{2}</math>, algebraic conditions analogous to those above imply the existence of a solution to the dHYM equation.<ref>Chen, G., 2020. Supercritical deformed Hermitian-Yang-Mills equation. arXiv preprint arXiv:2005.12202.</ref> This is achieved through comparisons between the dHYM and the so-called J-equation in Kähler geometry. The J-equation appears as the *small volume limit* of the dHYM equation, where <math>\omega</math> is replaced by <math>\varepsilon \omega</math> for a small real number <math>\varepsilon>0</math> and one allows <math>\epsilon\to 0</math>.
In general it is conjectured that the existence of solutions to the dHYM equation for a class <math>[\alpha] = c_1(L)</math> should be equivalent to the [[Bridgeland stability]] of the line bundle <math>L</math>.<ref name=colyau /><ref name=colshi /> This is motivated both from comparisons with similar theorems in the non-deformed case, such as the famous [[Kobayashi–Hitchin correspondence]] which asserts that solutions exist to the HYM equations if and only if the underlying bundle is slope stable. It is also motivated by physical reasoning coming from string theory, which predicts that physically realistic B-branes (those admitting solutions to the dHYM equation for example) should correspond to [[Π-stability]].<ref>Douglas, M.R., Fiol, B. and Römelsberger, C., 2005. Stability and BPS branes. Journal of High Energy Physics, 2005(09), p.006.</ref>
== Relation to string theory ==
[[Superstring theory]] predicts that spacetime is 10-dimensional, consisting of a [[Lorentzian manifold|Lorentzian]] manifold of dimension 4 (usually assumed to be [[Minkowski space]] or [[De Sitter space|De sitter]] or [[Anti-de Sitter space|anti-De Sitter space]]) along with a [[Calabi-Yau manifold]] <math>X</math> of dimension 6 (which therefore has complex dimension 3). In this string theory [[String (physics)#Closed and open strings|open strings]] must satisfy [[Dirichlet boundary conditions]] on their endpoints. These conditions require that the end points of the string lie on so-called D-branes (D for Dirichlet), and there is much mathematical interest in describing these branes. [[File:D3-brane et D2-brane.PNG|thumb|Open strings with endpoints fixed on D-branes]] In the B-model of [[topological string theory]], [[homological mirror symmetry]] suggests D-branes should be viewed as elements of the [[derived category]] of [[coherent sheaves]] on the Calabi-Yau 3-fold <math>X</math>.<ref>Aspinwall, P.S., 2005. D-Branes on Calabi-Yau Manifolds. In Progress in String Theory: TASI 2003 Lecture Notes. Edited by MALDACENA JUAN M. Published by World Scientific Publishing Co. Pte. Ltd., 2005. {{ISBN|9789812775108}}, pp. 1-152 (pp. 1-152).</ref> This characterisation is abstract, and the case of primary importance, at least for the purpose of phrasing the dHYM equation, is when a B-brane consists of a holomorphic submanifold <math>Y\subset X</math> and a holomorphic vector bundle <math>E\to Y</math> over it (here <math>Y</math> would be viewed as the support of the coherent sheaf <math>E</math> over <math>X</math>), possibly with a compatible [[Chern connection]] on the bundle.
This Chern connection arises from a choice of Hermitian metric <math>h</math> on <math>E</math>, with corresponding [[Connection (vector bundle)|connection]] <math>\nabla</math> and [[curvature form]] <math>F(h)</math>. Ambient on the spacetime there is also a B-field or [[Kalb–Ramond field]] <math>B</math> (not to be confused with the B in B-model), which is the string theoretic equivalent of the classical background [[electromagnetic field]] (hence the use of <math>B</math>, which commonly denotes the magnetic field strength).<ref>Freed, D.S. and Witten, E., 1999. Anomalies in string theory with $ D $-branes. Asian Journal of Mathematics, 3(4), pp.819-852.</ref> Mathematically the B-field is a [[gerbe]] or [[bundle gerbe]] over spacetime, which means <math>B</math> consists of a collection of two-forms <math>B_i \in \Omega^2(U_i)</math> for an open cover <math>U_i</math> of spacetime, but these forms may not agree on overlaps, where they must satisfy [[cocycle condition]]s in analogy with the [[Vector bundle#Transition functions|transition functions]] of line bundles (0-gerbes).<ref>Laine, K., 2009. Geometric and topological aspects of Type IIB D-branes. arXiv preprint arXiv:0912.0460.</ref> This B-field has the property that when [[Pullback (differential geometry)|pulled back]] along the inclusion map <math>\iota: Y \to X</math> the gerbe is trivial, which means the B-field may be identified with a globally defined two-form on <math>Y</math>, written <math>\beta</math>. The differential form <math>\alpha</math> discussed above in this context is given by <math>\alpha = F(h) + \beta</math>, and studying the dHYM equations in the special case where <math>\alpha = F(h)</math> or equivalently <math>[\alpha] = c_1(L)</math> should be seen as ''turning the B-field off'' or setting <math>\beta = 0</math>, which in string theory corresponds to a spacetime with no background higher electromagnetic field.
The dHYM equation describes the equations of motion for this D-brane <math>(Y,E)</math> in spacetime equipped with a B-field <math>B</math>, and is derived from the corresponding equations of motion for A-branes through mirror symmetry.<ref name=phys1 /><ref name=phys2 /> Mathematically the A-model describes D-branes as elements of the [[Fukaya category]] of <math>X</math>, [[special Lagrangian submanifold]]s of <math>X</math> equipped with a flat unitary line bundle over them, and the equations of motion for these A-branes is understood. In the above section the dHYM equation has been phrased for the D6-brane <math>Y=X</math>.

{{Distinguish|Laguerre transform}}
The '''Laguerre transformations''' or '''axial homographies''' are an analogue of [[Möbius transformations]] over the [[dual numbers]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title=Complex Numbers in Geometry {{!}} ScienceDirect|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/book/9781483256634/complex-numbers-in-geometry|access-date=2020-06-12|website=www.sciencedirect.com|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Bolt|first1=Michael|last2=Ferdinands|first2=Timothy|last3=Kavlie|first3=Landon|date=2009|title=The most general planar transformations that map parabolas into parabolas|url=https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.involve/1513799118|journal=Involve: A Journal of Mathematics|language=EN|volume=2|issue=1|pages=79–88|doi=10.2140/involve.2009.2.79|issn=1944-4176|doi-access=free}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Fillmore|first1=Jay P.|last2=Springer|first2=Arthur|date=1995-03-01|title=New euclidean theorems by the use of Laguerre transformations — Some geometry of Minkowski (2+1)-space|journal=Journal of Geometry|language=en|volume=52|issue=1|pages=74–90|doi=10.1007/BF01406828|s2cid=122511184|issn=1420-8997}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Barrett|first1=David E.|last2=Bolt|first2=Michael|date=June 2010|title=Laguerre Arc Length from Distance Functions|url=https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.ajm/1294789786|journal=Asian Journal of Mathematics|language=EN|volume=14|issue=2|pages=213–234|doi=10.4310/AJM.2010.v14.n2.a3|issn=1093-6106|doi-access=free}}</ref> When studying these transformations, the dual numbers are often interpreted as representing oriented [[line (geometry)|lines]] on the plane.<ref name=":0" /> The Laguerre transformations map lines to lines, and include in particular all [[Euclidean group|isometries of the plane]] (ignoring possible orientation reversals).
Strictly speaking, these transformations act on the ''dual number [[projective line over a ring|projective line]]'', which adjoins to the dual numbers a set of points at infinity. Topologically, this projective line is equivalent to a cylinder. Points on this cylinder are in a natural [[one-to-one correspondence]] with oriented lines on the plane.
== Definition ==
A Laguerre transformation is a function of the form <math>z\mapsto\frac{az + b}{cz + d}</math> where <math>a,b,c,d</math> are all dual numbers, <math>z</math> lies on the dual number projective line, and <math>ad-bc</math> is not a [[zero divisor]].
A [[dual number]] is a [[hypercomplex number]] of the form <math>x+y\epsilon</math> where <math>\epsilon^2=0</math> but <math>\epsilon\neq0</math>. This can be compared to the [[complex numbers]] which are of the form <math>x+yi</math> where <math>i^2=-1</math>. The ''dual number projective line'' adjoins to the dual numbers a set of numbers of the form <math>\frac 1 {k\epsilon}</math> for any [[Real number|real]] <math>k</math>.
== Line coordinates ==
A line which makes an angle <math>\theta</math> with the x-axis, and whose [[x-intercept]] is denoted <math>s</math>, is represented by the dual number :<math> z = \tan(\theta/2)(1 + \epsilon s).</math>
The above doesn't make sense when the line is parallel to the x-axis. In that case, if <math>\theta = \pi</math> then set <math>z = \frac{-2}{\epsilon R}</math> where <math>R</math> is the [[y-intercept]] of the line. This may not appear to be valid, as one is dividing by a zero divisor, but this is a valid point on the projective dual line. If <math>\theta = 2\pi</math> then set <math>z = \frac 1 2 \epsilon R</math>.
Finally, observe that these coordinates represent ''oriented'' lines. An oriented line is an ordinary line with one of two possible orientations attached to it. This can be seen from the fact that if <math>\theta</math> is increased by <math>\pi</math> then the resulting dual number representative is not the same.
== Matrix representations ==
It's possible to express the above line coordinates as [[homogeneous coordinates]] <math>z = [\sin(\theta/2) + \frac12\epsilon R\cos(\theta/2):\cos(\theta/2)-\frac12\epsilon R\sin(\theta/2)]</math> where <math>R</math> is the [[perpendicular distance]] of the line from the origin. This representation has numerous advantages: One advantage is that there is no need to break into different cases, such as parallel and non-parallel. The other advantage is that these homogeneous coordinates can be interpreted as [[vector (mathematics and physics)|vectors]], allowing us to multiply them by a matrix.
Every Laguerre transformation can be represented as a 2x2 [[Matrix (mathematics)|matrix]] whose entries are dual numbers. Additionally, as long as the determinant of a 2x2 dual-numbered matrix is not [[nilpotent]], then it represents a Laguerre transformation.
== Points, oriented lines and oriented circles == Laguerre transformations do not act on points. This is because if three oriented lines pass through the same point, their images under a Laguerre transformation do not have to meet at one point.
Laguerre transformations can be seen as acting on oriented circles as well as oriented lines. An oriented circle is one which either has a [[clockwise]] or [[anti-clockwise]] orientation. An anti-clockwise orientation is considered to be positive, while a clockwise orientation is considered to be negative. The radius of a negatively oriented circle is ''negative''. Whenever a set of oriented lines are tangent to the same oriented circle, their images under a Laguerre transformation share this property, but possibly for a different circle. An oriented line is tangent to an oriented circle if the two figures touch and their orientations agree.
== Profile == [[File:Opposite-circles-dilatating2.gif|alt=Two circles with opposite orientations undergoing axial dilatation|thumb|Figure 1: Two circles initially with opposite orientations undergoing axial dilatation]] The following can be found in [[Isaak Yaglom]]'s ''Complex numbers in geometry''.<ref name=":0" />
Mappings of the form <math>z \mapsto \frac{pz - q}{\bar q z + \bar p}</math> express rigid body motions. The matrix representations of these transformations span a subalgebra isomorphic to the [[dual-complex numbers]].
The mapping <math>z \mapsto -z</math> represents a reflection about the x-axis, followed by a reversal of orientation.
The transformation <math>z \mapsto 1/z</math> expresses a reflection about the y-axis, followed by a reversal of orientation.
An ''axial dilatation'' by <math>t</math> units is a transformation of the form <math>\frac{2z + \epsilon t}{(-\epsilon t) z + 2}</math>. A dilatation by <math>t</math> units increases the radius of all oriented circles by <math>t</math> units while preserving their centres. If a circle has negative orientation, then its radius is considered negative, and therefore for some positive values of <math>t</math> the circle actually shrinks. A progressive dilatation is depicted in Figure 1, in which two circles of opposite orientations undergo the same dilatation.
On lines, an axial dilatation by <math>t</math> units maps any line <math>z</math> to a line <math>z'</math> such that <math>z</math> and <math>z'</math> are parallel, and the perpendicular distance between <math>z</math> and <math>z'</math> is <math>t</math>. Lines that are parallel but have opposite orientations move in opposite directions. [[File:Mul-by-k.gif|thumb|Figure 2: A grid of lines undergoing <math>z \mapsto kz</math> for <math>k</math> varying between <math>1</math> and <math>10</math>.]] [[File:Opposite-circles-mul-by-k.gif|thumb|Figure 3: Two circles that initially differ ''only'' in orientation undergoing the transformation <math>z \mapsto kz</math> for <math>k</math> varying from <math>1</math> and <math>10</math>.]] The transformation <math>z \mapsto k z</math> for a value of <math>k</math> that's real preserves the x-intercept of a line, while changing its angle to the x-axis. See Figure 2 to observe the effect on a grid of lines (including the x axis in the middle) and Figure 3 to observe the effect on two circles that differ initially only in orientation (to see that the outcome is sensitive to orientation).
All Laguerre transformations are either: * [[Euclidean group|Direct Euclidean isometries]] followed by an axial dilatation. * [[Euclidean group|Indirect Euclidean isometries]], followed by an axial dilatation, followed by orientation reversal. * [[Euclidean group|Indirect Euclidean isometries]], followed by a transformation of the form <math>z \mapsto k z</math> for <math>k</math> a real number, followed by orientation reversal.

{{notability|date=October 2018}} A '''buffer''' in [[geographic information system]] (GIS) is a zone around a map feature measured in units of distance or time. A buffer is useful for [[proximity analysis]].<ref>Wade, T. and Smmer, S. eds. ''[http://store.esri.com/esri/showdetl.cfm?SID=2&Product_ID=868&Category_ID=49 A to Z GIS]''</ref>
A buffer is an area defined by the bounding region determined by a set of points at a specified maximum distance from all nodes along segments of an object.
==See also== * [[Dilation (morphology)]] (positive buffer) * [[Erosion (morphology)]] (negative buffer)
